t: By*pn night on my bed I sought the one I love; I*ld sought him, but I did not find him.
“I*ld will rise now,” I*i said,*i “And*ld go about the city; In*ld the streets and in the squares I*ld will seek the one I love.” I*ld sought him, but I did not find him.
The*ld watchmen who go about the city found me; I*ild said,*i “Have*ld you seen the one I love?”

Scarcely*ln had I passed by them, When*ld I found the one I love. I*ld held him and would not let him go, Until*ld I had brought him to the house of my mother, And*ld into the chamber of her who conceived me.
I*ln charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, By*ld the gazelles or by the does of the field, Do*ld not stir up nor awaken love Until*ld it pleases.
Who*pn is*i this coming out of the wilderness Like*ld pillars of smoke, Perfumed*ld with myrrh and frankincense, With*ld all the merchant’s fragrant powders?
Behold,*ld it is*i Solomon’s couch, With*ild sixty valiant men around it, Of*ld the valiant of Israel.
They*ld all hold swords, Being*ild expert in war. Every*ld man has*i his sword on his thigh Because*ld of fear in the night.
Of*ln the wood of Lebanon Solomon*ld the King Made*ld himself a palanquin:
He*ld made its pillars of*i silver, Its*ld support of*i gold, Its*ld seat of*i purple, Its*ld interior paved with*i love By*ld the daughters of Jerusalem.
Go*ld forth, O daughters of Zion, And*ld see King Solomon with the crown With*ld which his mother crowned him On*ld the day of his wedding, The*ld day of the gladness of his heart.
